issue.title: Add some complexity measures of modified files

repository.name: bugbug
repository.description: Platform for Machine Learning projects on Software Engineering

issue.body:
- [x] Size of modified file (before? after? both?) - Done in 97d514e1dbb24a1faa649feda5cc746ed7053fef.
- [x] Size of modified function (before? after? both?) - Done in 66d17b05d6fa624d9ed80c9202849ba61494f3ce.
- [x] Cyclomatic complexity (of the modified functions?)
- [ ] Number of tokens (whole file? modified functions? both?)
- [x] Parameter count of functions (whole file? modified functions? both?)
- [x] Number of exit points for functions
- [ ] Dependency count (e.g. number of #include, number of imports, etc.).
- [ ] What else?

There is a tool that does this (https://terryyin.github.io/lizard/), but it doesn't support all languages.

The solution for this would probably have something in common with the solution for #371.

body:
One way to do this is:
- Get the files before/after the commit with hg cat
- Remove comments from the files before/after using some language agnostic tool
- Calculate the diff of the two

Another way would be to just remove lines starting with // or between /* and */ in a diff, but this wouldn't be precise (in the case of multiline commits for example, if the diff is in the middle of the multiline commit).

The first option is likely way slower than the second, but it is more precise and would probably allow us to also do #372 more easily.
For removing comments, we could use a generic parser like pygments or tree-sitter.

issue.title: Collect size of files modified by the patch

repository.name: bugbug
repository.description: Platform for Machine Learning projects on Software Engineering

issue.body:
This can be considered as one of the complexity measures (see #372).

(Depends on #377, I'll rebase this after it's merged)

issue.title: Don't get file_copies from hg log

repository.name: bugbug
repository.description: Platform for Machine Learning projects on Software Engineering

issue.body:
It's pretty slow.
We need it for experience calculation, so we could move this step after the parse patch step.

body:
> * Get the files before/after the commit with hg cat

With hg cat, we also need to add the revision right? So how would we find the revision number for a particular commit?


> * Remove comments from the files before/after using some language agnostic tool

And we only want to know code lines added and not comment lines?

> With hg cat, we also need to add the revision right? So how would we find the revision number for a particular commit?

We can use the node of the commit (see in repository.py, we are already using hg cat now).

> And we only want to know code lines added and not comment li

Ideally both.

Okay, so with hg cat, we get the after file and for the before file, we'd use the previous commit from the list, right?

But why do we need to remove comment lines if we want to calculate both?

> Okay, so with hg cat, we get the after file and for the before file, we'd use the previous commit from the list, right?

Or we store the parent of the commit for each commit, getting it in hg_log.

> But why do we need to remove comment lines if we want to calculate both?

We don't *have to*, it's just a possible way to implement this.

> Or we store the parent of the commit for each commit, getting it in hg_log.

Oh yes, that would be a better option.

And for parsing files, I was thinking of first reading the whole file into a string then splitting into list of lines. For single line comments, we can just check the first char so parsing them should be easy. But for multi-line comments we can have a loop starting when we encounter ```/*``` or ```'''```, and keep counting the lines until we find the end.

> And for parsing files, I was thinking of first reading the whole file into a string then splitting into list of lines. For single line comments, we can just check the first char so parsing them should be easy. But for multi-line comments we can have a loop starting when we encounter /* or ''', and keep counting the lines until we find the end.

This doesn't really work, comments are often in the middle of a line.
Writing something to remove the comments ourselves is likely not going to be very precise, unless we spend a lot of time on it (it's not trivial at all).

For pygments, we can do something like this:

```
import pygments
from pygments.lexers import get_lexer_for_filename
from pygments.token import Comment

lexer = get_lexer_for_filename('abc.py')

tokens = list(lexer.get_tokens_unprocessed(code))

comments = []
for idx, token, text in tokens:
    if token in Comment:
        comments.append((idx, token, text))
```


But there are some problems. For some file formats like C, it gives the output for preprocessors like this:

```
[(0, Token.Comment.Preproc, '#'),
 (1, Token.Comment.Preproc, 'include'),
 (9, Token.Comment.PreprocFile, '<stdio.h>'),
 (18, Token.Comment.Preproc, '\n'),
```

And multi-line comments in python are treated as a doc token `Token.Literal.String.Doc`.

I don't see them as big problems, we simply have to handle those cases too.
I'd try tree-sitter though, it's probably better supported and very likely faster.

Do we need to this for some specific code files like C, Python or it can be any code file?

I'm asking this because for each language we want to parse, tree-sitter needs a language implementation. And for this, we'd need to clone the existing tree-sitter language repos and compile them before using.
We need to support the most used languages in Firefox, they are many (C/C++, Rust, JavaScript, Java, etc.).

> We need to support the most used languages in Firefox, they are many (C/C++, Rust, JavaScript, Java, etc.).

So should we clone and build all the language repositories beforehand or do this only when we encounter a file type for the first time?

> So should we clone and build all the language repositories beforehand or do this only when we encounter a file type for the first time?

We can start with the C/C++ one, after we get that working, we can add the others.

> @marco-c Can you please suggest me a way to calculate diff of two files.
I tried using difflib but the output for hg cat files is not really readable (for my case it it shows addition and deletions for every single character separately).

You can do something like this:
```Python
def do_diff(temp_dir, before, after):
    after_file = os.path.join(temp_dir, f'after')
    with open(after_file, 'wb') as f:
        f.write(after)

    proc = subprocess.Popen(['diff', '-u5', '--ignore-trailing-space', '--ignore-tab-expansion', '--ignore-space-change', '--ignore-all-space', '--ignore-blank-lines', '-', after_file], stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE, stdin=subprocess.PIPE)

    out, err = proc.communicate(before)

    assert proc.returncode in [0, 1]

    os.unlink(after_file)

    return out
```

> And for the implementation, I was thinking of first calculating the diff of file before and after and from the diff, take out all the lines added, and parse these lines to differentiate between comment and code. Would that be okay?

How would you handle multiline comments this way? If the multiline comment is starting before the context of the diff, you won't be able to know.
Also, how would you handle lines which contain both code and comment?

> Also, how would you handle lines which contain both code and comment?

tree_sitter does that automatically. It gives the index where a comment starts in a line.
Atleast for Python and C it does, I've checked. But in case of C, it doesn't do so if a comment is written before the semicolon. It is only able to differentiate comment and code in a single line if separated by a semicolon.


> BTW, @calixteman started looking at this.

Okay. 
And really sorry for the delay, I'm not able to get enough time to complete this.
